original: Majjhima Nikāya 140
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Dhātuvibhaṅgasutta
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga sutta
translated: The Analysis of the Elements

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā magadhesu cārikaṁ caramāno yena rājagahaṁ tadavasari;
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā magadhesu cārikam caramānaḥ yena rājagaham tat avasari
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in the Magadhan country and eventually arrived at Rājagaha.

original: yena bhaggavo kumbhakāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhaggavaṁ kumbhakāraṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: yena bhaggavaḥ kumbhakāraḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhaggavam kumbhakāram etat avoca
translated: He went to the potter Bhaggava and said to him:

original: “sace te, bhaggava, agaru viharemu āvesane ekarattan”ti.
analyzed: sace te bhaggava agaru viharemu āvesane
translated: “If it is not inconvenient for you, Bhaggava, I will stay one night in your workshop.”

original: “Na kho me, bhante, garu.
analyzed: na kho me bhante garu
translated: “It is not inconvenient for me, venerable sir.

original: Atthi cettha pabbajito paṭhamaṁ vāsūpagato.
analyzed: atthi ca ittha pabbajitaḥ paṭhamam vāsūpagataḥ
translated: But there is a clansman who has gone forth later than I have who is already staying there.

original: Sace so anujānāti, viharatha, bhante, yathāsukhan”ti.
analyzed: sace saḥ anujānāti viharatha bhante
translated: If he agrees, you may stay there as long as you like.”

original: Tena kho pana samayena pukkusāti nāma kulaputto bhagavantaṁ uddissa saddhāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.🔽So tasmiṁ kumbhakārāvesane paṭhamaṁ vāsūpagato hoti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena pukkusāti nāma kula puttaḥ bhagavantam uddissa saddhāya agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ  saḥ tasmin kumbhakāra āvesane paṭhamam vāsū upagataḥ hoti
translated: Now on that occasion a clansman named Pukkusati had gone forth later than the Blessed One had and was already staying in the potter’s workshop.

original: Atha kho bhagavā yenāyasmā pukkusāti tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ pukkusātiṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā yena āyasmā pukkusāti tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam pukkusātim etat avoca
translated: So the Blessed One went to Ven. Pukkusati and said to him: 🔽“If it is not inconvenient for you, friend Pukkusati, I will stay one night in the workshop.”

original: “sace te, bhikkhu, agaru viharemu āvesane ekarattan”ti.
analyzed: sace te bhikkhu agaru viharemu āvesane
translated: “If it’s not inconvenient for you, I’d like to stay one night in the workshop.”

original: “Urundaṁ, āvuso, kumbhakārāvesanaṁ.
analyzed: urundo āvuso kumbhakāra āvesana
translated: “The potter’s workshop is open.

original: Viharatāyasmā yathāsukhan”ti.
analyzed: viharata ayasmai
translated: Stay there as you like.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā kumbhakārāvesanaṁ pavisitvā ekamantaṁ tiṇasanthārakaṁ paññāpetvā nisīdi pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā kumbhakāra āvesanam pavisitvā ekamantam tiṇa santhārakam paññāpetvā nisīdi pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: The Buddha entered the workshop, prepared a straw mat in one corner, and sat down cross-legged, with his body straight, and established mindfulness right there.

original: Atha kho bhagavā bahudeva rattiṁ nisajjāya vītināmesi.
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā bahudeva rattim nisajjāya vītināmesi
translated: He then spent most of the night sitting.

original: Āyasmāpi kho pukkusāti bahudeva rattiṁ nisajjāya vītināmesi.
analyzed: āyasmā api kho pukkusāti bahu deva rattim nisajjāya vītināmesi
translated: Pukkusāti did the same.

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: The Buddha thought,

original: “pāsādikaṁ kho ayaṁ kulaputto iriyati.
analyzed: pāsādikam kho ayam kula putto iriyati
translated: “This young man is confident.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ puccheyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham puccheyyanti
translated: Why don’t I question him?”

original: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ pukkusātiṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān āyasmantam pukkusātim etat avoca
translated: And he said to Pukkusāti,

original: “kaṁsi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, uddissa pabbajito? Ko vā te satthā? Kassa vā tvaṁ dhammaṁ rocesī”ti?
analyzed: kasi tva bhikkhu uddissa pabbajitaḥ kaḥ vā te satthā kassa vā tvam dhammam rocesi iti
translated: “On whose account have you gone forth? Who is your teacher? In whose Dhamma do you delight?”

original: “Atthāvuso, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito.
analyzed: attha āvuso samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sakya putto sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ
translated: “There is a contemplative, a Sakyan son who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhagavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam kha pana bhagavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: And this good report about him has spread:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘Thus indeed is he the Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened one, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, happy one, knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the Blessed One.’

original: Tāhaṁ bhagavantaṁ uddissa pabbajito.
analyzed: tā aham bhagavantam uddissa pabbajitaḥ
translated: I went forth from the household life into homelessness under that Blessed One.

original: So ca me bhagavā satthā.
analyzed: saḥ ca me bhagavā satthā
translated: And that Blessed One is my teacher.

original: Tassa cāhaṁ bhagavato dhammaṁ rocemī”ti.
analyzed: tassa ca aham bhagavataḥ dhammam rocemi iti
translated: I delight in that Blessed One’s Dhamma.”

original: “Kahaṁ pana, bhikkhu, etarahi so bhagavā viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti.
analyzed: kaham pana bhikkhu etarahi saḥ bhagavā viharati araham sammāsambuddho ti
translated: “But, bhikkhu, where is that Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened, now living?”

original: “Atthāvuso, uttaresu janapadesu sāvatthi nāma nagaraṁ.
analyzed: attha āvuso uttaresu janapadesu sāvatthi nāma nagara
translated: “In the northern country, friend, there is a city named Savatthi.

original: Tattha so bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti.
analyzed: tattha saḥ bhagavā etarahi viharati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ iti
translated: That is where that Blessed One is living now.”

original: “Diṭṭhapubbo pana te, bhikkhu, so bhagavā;
analyzed: diṭṭha pubbaḥ pana te bhikkhu saḥ bhagavā
translated: “But, bhikkhu, have you ever seen that Blessed One before?

original: disvā ca pana jāneyyāsī”ti?
analyzed: disvā ca pana jāneyyā asi iti
translated: When you see him, will you recognize him?”

original: “Na kho me, āvuso, diṭṭhapubbo so bhagavā;
analyzed: na kho me āvuso diṭṭha pubbaḥ saḥ bhagavā
translated: “I have never seen that Blessed One before, friend,

original: disvā cāhaṁ na jāneyyan”ti.
analyzed: disvā ca aham na
translated: and when I see him I will not recognize him.”

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: Then the Blessed One thought:

original: “mamañca khvāyaṁ kulaputto uddissa pabbajito.
analyzed: khvā ayam kula putto uddissa pabbajitaḥ
translated: ‘This young man went forth with me.

original: Yannūnassāhaṁ dhammaṁ deseyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna ssa aham dhammam deseyyanti
translated: Let me teach him the Dhamma.’

original: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ pukkusātiṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān āyasmantam pukkusātim āmantesi
translated: Then the Buddha said to Pukkusāti,

original: “dhammaṁ te, bhikkhu, desessāmi.
analyzed: dhammam te bhikkhu desessāmi
translated: ‘I’ll teach you the Dhamma.

original: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇāhi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and pay careful attention, I will speak.’

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: evam āvuso iti kho āyasmā pukkusa ati bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: ‘Yes, friend,’ Pukkusāti replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “‘Cha dhāturo ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso cha phassāyatano aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro caturādhiṭṭhāno;
analyzed: cha bhikkhu puriso cha phassa āyatano aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro catura adhiṭṭhāno
translated: ‘A person consists of six elements, six spheres of contact, and eighteen mental preoccupations. He has four foundations and his mind is established in four ways.

original: yattha ṭhitaṁ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccati.
analyzed: yattha ṭhitam maññassavāḥ na pavattanti maññassave kho pana na pavattamāne muni santo ti vuccati
translated: When he is established in this, his obsessions do not overwhelm him. When his obsessions are not overwhelming him, he is called a sage at peace.

original: Paññaṁ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
analyzed: paññam na ppamajjeyya saccam anurakkheyya cāgam anubrūheyya santim eva so sikkheyya ati
translated: He should not be negligent regarding wisdom, should preserve truth, should practice generosity, and should train for peace.’

original: ayamuddeso dhātuvibhaṅgassa.
analyzed: ayam uddesaḥ dhātu vibhaṅgassa
translated: This is the summary of the exposition of the elements.

original: ‘Cha dhāturo ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: cha bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘A person consists of six elements’—

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: this is said. And why is this said?

original: Chayimā, bhikkhu, dhātuyo—
analyzed: chayimā bhikkhu dhātuyaḥ
translated: There are these six elements:

original: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu ākāsa dhātu viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element.

original: ‘Cha dhāturo ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: cha bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This person consists of six elements,’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: that is what was said. And this is why it was said.

original: ‘Cha phassāyatano ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: cha phassa āyatano bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This person consists of six sense fields,’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: that’s what I said. And why did I say that?

original: Cakkhusamphassāyatanaṁ, sotasamphassāyatanaṁ, ghānasamphassāyatanaṁ, jivhāsamphassāyatanaṁ, kāyasamphassāyatanaṁ, manosamphassāyatanaṁ.
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa āyatana sota samphassa āyatana ghāna samphassa āyatana jivhā samphassa āyatana kāya samphassa āyatana manas samphassa āyatana
translated: The sense fields of eye contact, ear contact, nose contact, tongue contact, body contact, and mind contact.

original: ‘Cha phassāyatano ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: cha phassa āyatano bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This person consists of six sense fields,’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: that’s what I said. And this is why I said it.

original: ‘Aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This person consists of eighteen kinds of mental exploration,’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: that’s what I said. And why did I say that?

original: Cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā somanassaṭṭhāniyaṁ rūpaṁ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhāniyaṁ rūpaṁ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṁ rūpaṁ upavicarati;
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam disvā somanassa ṭṭhāniyam rūpam upavicarati domanassa ṭṭhāniyam rūpam upavicarati upekkhā ṭṭhāniyam rūpam upavicarati
translated: On seeing a form with the eye, he attends inappropriately, and so recollection of the Buddha, etc., is not established in him.

original: sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…🔽ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā pe  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: On hearing a sound with the ear…🔽On smelling an odour with the nose…

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: On tasting a flavour with the tongue…

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: On touching a tangible with the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya somanassaṭṭhāniyaṁ dhammaṁ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhāniyaṁ dhammaṁ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṁ dhammaṁ upavicarati—
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya somanassa ṭṭhāniyam dhammaṃ upavicarati domanassa ṭṭhāniyam dhammaṃ upavicarati upekkhā ṭṭhāniyam dhammaṃ upavicarati
translated: On cognizing a mind-object with the mind, he attends inappropriately, and so recollection of the Buddha, etc., is not established in him.

original: iti cha somanassupavicārā, cha domanassupavicārā, cha upekkhupavicārā.
analyzed: iti cha somanassa upavicārā cha domanassa upavicārā cha upekkhu upavicārā
translated: Thus there are six kinds of inappropriate attention upon forms, six upon sounds, six upon odours, six upon flavours, six upon tangible objects, and six upon mind-objects.

original: ‘Aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This man has eighteen kinds of mental exploration’—

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: this is what was said. And in reference to this was it said.

original: ‘Caturādhiṭṭhāno ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: catura adhiṭṭhānaḥ bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This man has four foundations’—

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: this is said. And in reference to what was this said?

original: Paññādhiṭṭhāno, saccādhiṭṭhāno, cāgādhiṭṭhāno, upasamādhiṭṭhāno.
analyzed: paññā adhiṭṭhāno sacca adhiṭṭhāno cāga adhiṭṭhāno upasama adhiṭṭhāno
translated: The basis of wisdom, the basis of truth, the basis of relinquishment, and the basis of peace.

original: ‘Caturādhiṭṭhāno ayaṁ, bhikkhu, puriso’ti—
analyzed: catura adhiṭṭhānaḥ bhikkhu puriso ti
translated: ‘This person has four bases,’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: that is what was said. And this is why it was said.

original: ‘Paññaṁ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
analyzed: paññam na ppamajjeyya saccam anurakkheyya cāgam anubrūheyya santim eva so sikkheyya ati
translated: ‘One should not be negligent regarding wisdom, one should preserve truth, one should practice relinquishment, and one should train for peace.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was said. And this is why it was said.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhu, paññaṁ nappamajjati?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhu paññam na appamajjati
translated: And how, bhikkhu, does one not neglect wisdom?

original: Chayimā, bhikkhu, dhātuyo—
analyzed: chayimā bhikkhu dhātuyaḥ
translated: There are these six elements:

original: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu ākāsa dhātu viññāṇa dhātu
translated: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhu, pathavīdhātu?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhu pathavī dhātu
translated: What, bhikkhu, is the earth element?

original: Pathavīdhātu siyā ajjhattikā siyā bāhirā.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu siyā ajjhattikā siyā bāhirā
translated: The earth element may be either internal or external.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhu, ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhu ajjhattikā pathavī dhātu
translated: What is the internal earth element?

original: Yaṁ ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ kakkhaḷaṁ kharigataṁ upādinnaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: yam ajjhattam paccattam kakkhaḷam khari gatam
translated: Whatever internally, belonging to oneself, is solid, solidified, and clung-to,

original: kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ hadayaṁ yakanaṁ
analyzed: kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakkam hadayam
translated: that is, head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung,🔽or whatever else exists internally, belonging to oneself, that is solid, solidified, and clung-to—this is called the internal earth element.

original: kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, yaṁ vā panaññampi kiñci🔽ajjhattaṁ paccattaṁ kakkhaḷaṁ kharigataṁ upādinnaṁ—
analyzed: kilomakam pihakam papphāsam antam anta guṇam udariyam yam vā pana aññam pi kiñci  ajjhattam paccattam kakkhaḷam khari gatam upādinna
translated: the liver, the midriff, the spleen, the contents of the stomach, the contents of the intestines, excrement, or whatever else is hard, solid, and clung-to in oneself.

original: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhu, ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhu ajjhattikā pathavī dhātu
translated: This, bhikkhu, is called the internal earth element.

original: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavīdhātu pathavīdhāturevesā.
analyzed: yā ca iva kho pana ajjhattikā pathavī dhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavī dhātu pathavī dhātuḥ eva isā
translated: Now the internal earth element and the external earth element are simply the earth element.

original: ‘Taṁ netaṁ mama nesohamasmi na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: tam na itam mama na isā aham asmi na mā isā attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya daṭṭhabba
translated: This should be seen as it actually is with proper wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’

original: Evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindati, pathavīdhātuyā cittaṁ virājeti.
analyzed: evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya disvā pathavī dhātuyā nibbindati pathavī dhātuyā cittam virājeti
translated: When one sees it thus as it actually is with proper wisdom, one becomes disenchanted with the earth element and makes the mind dispassionate towards the earth element.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhu, āpodhātu?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhu āpodhātu
translated: “And what, bhikkhu, is the water element?

original: Āpodhātu siyā ajjhattikā siyā bāhirā.
analyzed: āpodhātu siyā ajjhattikā siyā bāhirā
translated: The water element may be either internal or external.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhu, ajjhattikā āpodhātu?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhu ajjhattikā āpodhātu
translated: And what, bhikkhu, is the internal water element?

translated: Conceit is a disease, a tumour, a dart.🔽But when a sage has gone beyond all conceits,

original: Sabbamaññitānaṁ tveva, bhikkhu, samatikkamā muni santoti vuccati.
analyzed: sabbamaññitānam tu eva bhikkhu samatikkamā muni santo ti vuccati
translated: he is called a sage at peace.

original: Muni kho pana, bhikkhu, santo na jāyati, na jīyati, na mīyati, na kuppati, na piheti.
analyzed: muni kho pana bhikkhu santaḥ na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na kuppati na piheti
translated: A sage at peace is not born, does not grow old, does not die, does not tremble or shake.

original: Tañhissa, bhikkhu, natthi yena jāyetha, ajāyamāno kiṁ jīyissati, ajīyamāno kiṁ mīyissati, amīyamāno kiṁ kuppissati, akuppamāno kissa pihessati?
analyzed: tat hissa bhikkhu natthi yena jāyetha a jāyamānaḥ kim jīyissati a jīyamānaḥ kim mīyissati a mīyamānaḥ kim kuppissati a kuppamānaḥ kissa pihessati
translated: There is nothing in him by which he might be born. Since he is not born, how will he grow old? Since he does not grow old, how will he die? Since he does not die, how will he tremble or shake?

original: ‘Yattha ṭhitaṁ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccatī’ti—
analyzed: yattha ṭhitam maññassavāḥ na pavattanti maññassave kho pana na pavattamāne muni santo ti vuccati iti
translated: ‘When one is standing in the deathless, the conceivings do not occur. When the conceivings do not occur, one is called a sage at peace.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: This is the meaning of what the Blessed One said in ‘The Analysis of the Sixfold Sphere of Contact’ in ‘The Collection of Long Sayings.’

original: Imaṁ kho me tvaṁ, bhikkhu, saṅkhittena chadhātuvibhaṅgaṁ dhārehī”ti.
analyzed: imam kho me tva bhikkhu saṅkhittena cha dhātu vibhaṅgam dhārehi iti
translated: “Bhikkhu, you should remember the six elements in brief in this way.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā pukkusāti
translated: Then the venerable Pukkusati

original: “satthā kira me anuppatto, sugato kira me anuppatto, sammāsambuddho kira me anuppatto”ti uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: satthā kira me anuppatto sugataḥ kira me anuppatto sammāsambuddho kira me anuppatto ti uṭṭhāya āsanā ekasam cīvaram katvā bhagavataḥ pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: “The Teacher has come to me! The Fortunate One has come to me! The Buddha has come to me!” and after rising from his seat, and arranging his outer robe on one shoulder, he placed his head at the Fortunate One’s feet, and said this to the Fortunate One:

original: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ bhagavantaṁ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṁ amaññissaṁ.
analyzed: accayaḥ ma bhante accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala bhagavantam āvuso vādena samudācaritabbam amaññissa
translated: “I have made a mistake, reverend Sir, in that I was foolish, confused, and unskillful, in that I thought you should be addressed as ‘friend’.

original: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
analyzed: tassa me bhante bhagavā accayam accayataḥ paṭiggaṇhātu āyatim savarāya ati
translated: Please accept this mistake from me, reverend Sir, as a mistake, and I restrain myself in the future.”

original: “Taggha tvaṁ, bhikkhu, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṁ amaññittha.
analyzed: taggha tva bhikkhu accayaḥ accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala yam mam tvam āvuso vādena samudācaritabbam amaññittha
translated: “Surely, monk, you have made a mistake, in that you were foolish, confused, and unskillful, in that you thought I should be addressed as ‘friend’.

original: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, bhikkhu, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
analyzed: yatas ca kho tva bhikkhu accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikarosi tam te mayam paṭiggaṇhāma
translated: But since you have seen your mistake as a mistake, and have made amends in accordance with the Dhamma, we forgive you.

original: Vuddhihesā, bhikkhu, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjatī”ti.
analyzed: vuddhi hesā bhikkhu ariyassa vinaye yaḥ accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikaroti āyatim savaram āpajjati iti
translated: This is the growth in this Dhamma and Discipline, that one who has committed an offense sees it as an offense, confesses it as it should be confessed, and undertakes restraint in the future.”

original: “Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike upasampadanti
translated: “Venerable Sir, I would receive the full ordination from the Buddha.”

original: “Paripuṇṇaṁ pana te, bhikkhu, pattacīvaran”ti?🔽“Na kho me, bhante, paripuṇṇaṁ pattacīvaran”ti.
analyzed: paripuṇṇam pana te bhikkhu patta cīvaranti  na kho me bhante paripuṇṇam patta cīvaranti
translated: “But, monk, is your bowl and robes complete?”🔽“No, my bowl and robes are not complete.”

original: “Na kho, bhikkhu, tathāgatā aparipuṇṇapattacīvaraṁ upasampādentī”ti.
analyzed: na kho bhikkhu tathāgatāḥ a paripuṇṇa patta cīvaram upasampādenti iti
translated: “Monks, the Buddhas don’t give the full ordination to anyone whose bowl and robes are incomplete.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pattacīvarapariyesanaṁ pakkāmi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā patta cīvara pariyesanam pakkāmi
translated: After rejoicing in and approving of the Buddha’s words, Venerable Pukkusāti got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left to search for a bowl and robes.

original: Atha kho āyasmantaṁ pukkusātiṁ pattacīvarapariyesanaṁ carantaṁ vibbhantā gāvī jīvitā voropesi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmantam pukkusātim patta cīvara pariyesanam carantam vibbhantā gāvī jīvitā voropesi
translated: While he was searching for a bowl and robes, a stray cow killed him.

original: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho sambahulāḥ bhikkhū yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: Then a large number of monks went to the Buddha, and after paying homage to him, they sat down at one side

original: “yo so, bhante, pukkusāti nāma kulaputto bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ bhante pukkusāti nāma kula puttaḥ bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovaditaḥ saḥ kālaṅkato
translated: “Venerable sir, the clansman Pukkusati, who was advised by the Blessed One in brief, has died.

original: Tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti?
analyzed: tassa kā gati kaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti
translated: What is his destination? What is his future state?”

original: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, pukkusāti kulaputto paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṁ, na ca maṁ dhammādhikaraṇaṁ vihesesi.
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ bhikkhave pukkusāti kula putto paccapādi dhammassa anudhamma na ca mama dhamma adhikaraṇam vihesesi
translated: “Monks, the clansman Pukkusati was wise. He practiced in accordance with the Dhamma and did not trouble me on account of the Dhamma.

original: Pukkusāti, bhikkhave, kulaputto pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
analyzed: pukkusāti bhikkhave kula putto pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokāti
translated: The clansman Pukkusati, monks, has destroyed the five lower fetters. He has become one who attains final knowledge early in this very life, one who attains final knowledge immediately after death, or one who attains final knowledge without exertion. He is incapable of falling away from that attainment.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: Elated, those monks delighted in the Blessed One’s statement.

original: Dhātuvibhaṅgasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dasamaṁ.
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga suttam niṭṭhitam dasama
translated: The tenth section on the analysis of the elements is finished.
